data.title: Sleeper Mobile DAC/Amp
data.body:
95% of people will buy this just to be able to connect their wired headphones to their iPhone, but what they won't realize is this a very capable DAC/amp (emphasis more on the DAC) that powers relatively low impedance headphones with ease and measures incredibly well for the price. I plugged HD58x's into these (relatively easy to power) and they got plenty loud enough and sounded great. You can tell when going from something like a Liquid Spark or JDS Atom to this that the openness and separation does suffer a little bit, but it's shocking how close they are.

What this won't do is properly power high impedance headphones. It's not a ton of power into 32 ohms, so when you start to get to 250 ohms+ it's not capable enough to take full advantage of what those headphones can do.

Still, this is absolutely the best DAC/amp you can buy for under $10 and represents one of the best values in audio in my opinion. I didn't really need this for any specific reason, but I bought it to play around with and am super pleased with its performance. I'll still use my desktop setup most of the time, but if I want to walk around the house and don't want to use Bluetooth, this is the only way to go.

If you're just looking for a converter and don't understand or care about most of what is written above, you'll also be very pleased. Essentially, these will make your headphones sound better while providing a strong, secure connection into your phone. I can't recommend this product enough.

data.title: Dead simple Apple Lightning DAC.
data.body: It does a single job and does it very well. Construction appears to be very good. I have four of these - two for Lightening and two for USB-C - and zero issues have ever arisen. Fantastic low price is routinely available.

data.title: Best Affordable DAC
data.body:
From your every day individuals who want to listen to music with wired headphones to heavy audiophiles, the Apple 3.5mm headphone adapter is well known. It seems to be the most recommended when it comes to an affordable DAC in the in-ear audiophile world. I am currently using it paired with some studio monitors and it is fantastic. They also gave me no problems when using my IEMs and listening on my iPhone.

Definitely recommend for anyone who is looking for an affordable, portable DAC.

data.body: Worked great, amazing sound quality. Never had any issues with the sound cutting out when twisting certain ways. But it did stop working randomly after 1 year and 10 months. Wire never frayed and stayed together well.

data.title: Works great
data.body:
We had tried aftermarket brand of earphones and did not like them as the sound quality was not as good.
The lightning adapter plug allowed us to use apple ear buds we still had from previous phones that were still in good shape and worked well; same sound quality as apple has - no degradation. Will order a couple more to convert additional earbuds we have.

data.title: Get this Apple OEM adapter instead of cheap knock offs
data.body: Forget buying the cheaper non-Apple adapters, even if it's a multi-pack for less or the same price. They either don't work correctly or quickly break. Their ratings might be over 4 stars but the genuine reviews are mostly negative. Get the Apple one, shipped and sold by Amazon.

data.title: Works as described
data.body: It‚Äôs a good sturdy adapter, works as it should :)

data.title: Hit or miss function, very small and flimsy....
data.body:
Got this for an iPhone SE to connect to a variety of audio setups..... Stand alone speakers didn't seem to be an issue (even ones that have interference issues with some computers) ..... A high quality, though old [at this point] home theater system with 8 speakers did not work with this cable (and I regularly connect computers to the system as well as phones and other devices with headphone jacks without a single problem) .... The phone itself has no issue recognizing the cable, though it classifies it as an input device, rather than what it is, output. The home theater didn't recognize audio input with this cable. And THAT is the main reason for my returning the item.... I wanted to connect the iPhone SE to have it stream music (mainly 'cause the battery life is so much better on the phone than on any computer)..... Also got a little odd in the car..... To begin with, this cable is EXTREMELY short.... I do have a high end extender for headphone jack type cables that has worked with everything I've used it on (including other phones & computers), BUT, when I plugged it into this lightning adapter, the car's stereo didn't recognize the input at all..... Directly connecting the short lighting cable to the car's stereo had mixed results --- cutting in and out at random....

So, this cable may be good for some folks and not so much for others. You have to consider the age and complexity of the equipment you intend to connect to --- some older, more technical stuff, may not work; old speakers (tested with a pair that's 40yrs old) work just fine, but a home theater type system is a diff't beast.

The one thing this short little cable definitely has going for it is its resistance to interference. No matter what speaker I connected it to, there was never an interference issue .... I actually tinkered a bit with the two large speakers from the high end home theater system to allow them to connect directly to this lightning cable as standalone units to test the quality of the sound..... Variety of music types ALL came through with clear, crisp sound..... The low ends, deep bass, etc. all sound exactly as they should. There is no distortion or loss at all.

Volume control..... The cable itself doesn't have its own volume control (and given the length of the cable, why would it be needed?) , however it doesn't interfere with the phone's volume control capabilities at all.

That all said..... I returned the cable because it doesn't work where it's most needed. Also concerned about the fact that it registers with the phone as an input device; this opens the door for the cable to not work at all at any point.

data.title: Seamless Solution for In-Flight Entertainment
data.body: When it comes to keeping our daughter entertained during long flights, having reliable audio connectivity is an absolute must. The adapter seamlessly connects our daughter's headphones to our iPhone, allowing her to enjoy her favorite movies and shows with crystal-clear audio quality. The setup is quick and hassle-free, making it ideal for on-the-go entertainment.

data.title: Not overpriced and works in both directions
data.body:
I use lightning adapters to carry outside signals into the iPhone, as well as out to audio accessories.
These work both ways, unlike some competing products, and surprisingly (for Apple) are relatively inexpensive. Of course, it's too early to know how durable it will be, and thanks to the EU the lighting connector will likely be obsolete on future iPhones.

data.title: If your iPhone doesn't have a 1/8" headphone jack you need this. Cheap enough.
data.body:
This adapter takes the digital output of the iPhone Lightning jack, does analog to digital conversion within the plug, then outputs analog audio to a traditional stereo headphone jack. It's technically "CD quality", but it would be nice if Apple offered a better "Pro" version that would decode something closer to lossless at, say, $40. (and more durable). Most won't be able to tell the difference (or care) and this is cheap, but aftermarket lossless A/D convertors are 10-20x the cost of this. The iPhone is capable. Lightning is capable. The hardware is willing, but the adapter is weak.

Apple: here is a "Pro" opportunity for low hanging fruit.

data.title: Good
data.body: I bought this like 2+ years ago. But always worked great for me. Only reason I‚Äôm not using it now is because I got the new iphone15 promax and they are now usbc.

data.title: Tiny, not expensive, sounds decent
data.body: This is not a Bluetooth adapter. It's a tiny DAC that converts the digital audio from your iPhone's lightning connector into an analog signal that old-school 3.5 headphones and normal analog stereos can use. And considering how small it is, and the reasonable price, it does an excellent job at that one thing. If you want a better DAC than this for your iPhone, you should look at things like the Audioquest Dragonfly Red and Cobalt. Note that those cost at least 10x more, and for only about 3% better sound.

data.title: Apple Lightning to 3.5 mm Headphone Jack Adapter: A Reliable Link
data.body:
Step into the world of audio connectivity with the Apple Lightning to 3.5 mm Headphone Jack Adapter, a compact and efficient solution for your audio needs. This adapter is a shining example of functionality meeting simplicity, making it an essential accessory for Apple device users.

The first thing you'll appreciate is its plug-and-play ease. There's no need for complicated setups or software installations. It's as straightforward as it gets - plug it in, and you're ready to enjoy your music or podcasts with your favorite headphones.

The sound quality remains uncompromised with this adapter. It delivers clear, crisp audio, maintaining the high standards that Apple users have come to expect. Whether you're listening to music, watching videos, or taking calls, the sound is consistently excellent.

Durability is another strong suit of this adapter. It's built to withstand daily wear and tear, making it a reliable companion for your commutes, travels, or home use. It's a small accessory that's big on resilience.

The compact design is a bonus, making it easy to carry around. It's unobtrusive and can easily fit in your pocket, purse, or backpack. This adapter is always there when you need it, without taking up unnecessary space.

In conclusion, the Apple Lightning to 3.5 mm Headphone Jack Adapter is a testament to the saying, 'good things come in small packages.' It's a straightforward, high-quality, and durable solution for connecting your headphones to your Apple devices. This adapter is not just a piece of hardware; it's a bridge to your audio world.

data.title: iPhone adaptor for headphones
data.body: It might seem like a small thing, but if you have an iPhone 13 or newer, you need this little adaptor to plug earphones into your iPhone. An adaptor comes with each iPhone. My husband lost his so I got him this replacement. Works like magic!

data.title: Awesome Little Adapters!
data.body: My wife and I use these when riding our e-Bikes. We plug a standard wired ear bud into our ears and connect the other end into our iPhones using this adapter. Then we call each other and stay connected while riding. Very easy and inexpensive way to communicate while riding our e-Bikes, plus if the ear bud falls out or gets damaged somehow, that's better than losing or damaging a more expensive bluetooth ear bud. Yeah we really like this adapter!

data.body:
Wired headphones are just superior to wireless ones. There are only so many times I can hear "Ah, but you haven't tried THESE wireless headphones!" Yes, I have. Very expensive ones. Just, no. This is aside from the fact devices like AirPods fall out of my ears when I lean over, bend over, make any kind of movement, etc. Yes, I am putting them on correctly. Yes, I have the right size.

I have an exercise playlist that just HAS to be LOUD. I'm so delighted to have a way to plug my wired headphones in to my phone and turn up the volume. The sound quality is great. I'm sorry I didn't think of getting one of these sooner.

data.title: Serenity in sound
data.body:
Elevating my audio experience, the Apple Lightning to 3.5 mm Headphone Jack Adapter seamlessly integrates with my Apple devices, bringing a touch of serenity to my listening sessions.
Crafted with precision, this adapter transforms the ordinary into extraordinary. The seamless connection ensures a flawless transfer of sound, maintaining the purity of every note. There's no interruption in sound or call quality, allowing me to immerse myself in music or conversation without missing a beat.
Its petite design hides a powerhouse of potential, enabling uninterrupted enjoyment of my favorite tunes or crystal-clear conversations. In a world of connectivity, this adapter is a stylish bridge, harmonizing my devices effortlessly. Simplifying my audio landscape with grace, it's a must-have accessory for those who value both form and function.

data.title: TLD[on't]R! Worked great‚Äîseemed authentic
data.body:
I'm on this page to purchase a new adapter just like the one (or 2?)I previously used, which seems to have been lost by the certain kiddo of mine who loses stuff as often as I do‚Äîor misplaced by me.

Okay, first, so I first purchased the now-lost adapter from *this* listing/this seller, as Amazon points out at the top of this page. (See pic.)

Second, even minor audio stuff is a bigger deal to me than (I really imagine) to most people, as my actual professional is that of a professional "art music" ["classical" musician, as most understandably say‚Äîbut that term has some problems of which of course I'll spare you the details here]. So, all I'm saying is, I notice audio quality, & I have little patience even for arguably poor CALL quality or whatnot. For these reasons, I think I'm qualified to assure you.

Last time I got this from this retailer, there was, as I recall, no concern about any generic-type packagIng‚Äîno concern about it being a knock-off immediately.

More important, as this was my first such adapter, I remember being quite pleasantly pleased with everything about it. I used it with whichever iPhone(s) I had at the time for calls & on-the-go media listening, as well as a with my iPad Pro for listening, recording, etc., with earbuds when whatever I was listening to was not some huge deal, and for more-huge-deal listening with my beloved Audio-Technicas,, a [surprisingly great, particularly for noise cancelling] paid of Bose, or either of my "audiophile" young kids' high-end Sonys (&, btw, I'm not ax mum who gets my kids unduly high-end things, but I found those, obviously MAjorly mistakenly under-priced on Amazon Prime Now ~15 months ago, so I of course snatched those instead of getting the correctly priced cheap ones).

NO PROBLEM AT ALL with this adapter, for however long I had it readily available (maybe over a year), & I've personally no reason to have believs the seller has "gone to the dark side" or whatever.

BUT, as I'm ordering a couple of so more of these today for same-day delivery, I PROMISE you that if there's ANY problem, I'll add an addendum to this. Okay? (And, yeah, I KNOW a lot of folks say stuff like that, but they unexpectedly get too busy, or forget, or have become so fed up with Amz they can't tolerate anything concerning reviews. I get it. But, when it comes to anything that disrupts my music-listening or playing, I'll hop on Amazon to warn folks. (Not the case [as consistently] with so many of the not-well-considered, purchased, cheap clothing, my very rare "home decor" purchases or whatever.

And, you know, I used to review thingx rather diligently because the review set-up used to be (long, long ago) really helpful. But now, there are so many maddeningly obvious fake reviews, and maddeningly non-obvious (paid-for)!fake reviews‚Äîsellersv getting pressured to hype their often-pointless drop-ship merchandise, or (even worse) sellers paying folks to rip apart competitors' wares. The system now has too little utility for me to bother with it.

But, as I promised, if there's a problem with my new purchase here, I'll let you know. If I don't (by, like, early February 2021), you can assume I'm pleased as punch with the new purchase (or that something terrible has happened in, or to, my life‚Äîbut as I'm confined to home, with good security system, & as we're in good health these days, just assume the news adapters all worked out.

Okay. Metrorail stop coming up, so I'll end this odd review with verrbose, general commentary, Take care.

I have purchased this twice, once for myself and once more recently for my child.
The first one is still going strong with no issues and I am pretty hard on it.
The one purchased earlier in 2023 barely lasted three months before it flat out stopped working. My kid is bummed as he has an older phone and cannot listen to music. He wants another for Christmas but needless to say, I am pretty hesitant about purchasing again.

data.body: The annoying thing about Apple as we Apple users know is that they keep changing ports, plugs, cables, etc. so you keep needing to buy new plugs, cables, etc. This adaptor helped connect my original earpods to my iphone 13. Of course, the new earpods I bought would not work with this adaptor! So be super careful about what you buy, especially if you are offered a package deal of items that ultimately won't work together anyway!
